In un momento di rapida trasformazione del mercato immobiliare, cresce l’interesse per progetti che uniscano qualità della vita, comfort moderno e redditività stabile. È il caso di Bekatown, complesso situato ad Aranđelovac (Serbia), a soli 45 minuti da Belgrado, sei minuti a piedi dal centro cittadino e cinque dalla spa di Bukovička. Come riportato da ekapija.com, Srđan Mitrović, responsabile delle vendite di Bekament, spiega che Bekatown non è una località turistica stagionale, ma una comunità multifunzionale che integra residenza, attività commerciale, wellness e business.  

Il progetto include il più grande centro benessere del Sud-Est Europa, una passeggiata con oltre 100 unità commerciali, una sala congressi e uno stadio sportivo, garantendo attività e affluenza tutto l’anno. Gli alloggi sono dotati di tecnologie “smart home”, con soluzioni energeticamente efficienti. Il modello di investimento proposto è “acquista, arreda, lascia a noi”: la gestione completa degli affitti avviene in modalità alberghiera, assicurando un reddito passivo senza impegno operativo per il proprietario. Il ritorno sull’investimento è stimato intorno ai sette anni.  

Secondo Mitrović, la chiave di successo risiede nella combinazione di localizzazione strategica, contenuti attrattivi 365 giorni l’anno e gestione professionale, elementi essenziali per investimenti sostenibili al di fuori delle grandi città. Per le imprese italiane del settore immobiliare e dei servizi alberghieri, il progetto rappresenta un potenziale canale per partnership o fornitura di soluzioni tecnologiche e di arredo per residenze ad alto standard.

title_en: Melanija Pavlović, Director of JAF Serbia: Our goal is to remain leader that sets standards on the wood industry market
title_it: JAF Serbia punta su sostenibilità e leadership nel legno
content_en: (Photo: JAF Srbija) For decades, the JAF company has been a synonym for variety and quality in the segment of wood and decorative materials. As the general director Melanija Pavlović said in an interview for eKapija, in their business they are guided by the principle of offering the market everything that modern design and architecture require. At a time when more and more people are writing and talking about environmental protection, the JAF company says that for them sustainability is not just a trend, but an essential part of their business philosophy, so they have been setting standards in the area of ​​responsible use of wood and protection of natural resources for a long time. And not only that, in this company they are investing in the modernization of warehouses and machines that contribute to energy efficiency and reducing waste. What sets JAF apart on the market is that they offer clients the opportunity to offer the entire solution in one place - from materials to technical support and logistics. This saves time for their business partners and increases the efficiency in project implementation. The company`s plans are directed towards further growth and modernization, and the main goal is to remain a leader that sets standards - both in terms of quality and professionalism, and in terms of sustainable and responsible business. The general director of the company, Melanija Pavlović, in an interview for our portal, reveals what trends are shaping the market for floor coverings and wood materials, speaks about the importance of the new distribution center in Niš, but also about the challenges she faces as a woman at the head of a large company in a traditionally male-dominated industry, and about the ways how JAF encourages women`s empowerment within the company. (Photo: JAF Srbija) How do you see the current trends when it comes to floor coverings and parquets, and how is JAF responding to the growing market demands in this segment? - The floor covering market today is characterized by three main trends – naturalness, sustainability and functional design. Customers increasingly strive for materials that are authentic, environmentally friendly and easy to maintain, while architects and investors seek flexibility and the possibility of personalization. Parquet is coming back into focus as a symbol of home warmth, but also as a sophisticated element of modern interiors. At JAF, we have been building an offer in line with those expectations for years. Our assortment includes parquets and floor coverings from top European manufacturers, from classic solid floors to multi-layered parquets and decking systems for exteriors. We place special emphasis on products with FSC® and PEFC™ certificates that confirm the sustainable origin of the wood. Something that is definitely a trend in the world and will be used more and more is SPC vinyl flooring. Our professional teams provide support to customers, architects and contractors through advice on the selection, installation and maintenance of flooring solutions. In this way, we combine the beauty of natural materials with modern technological standards and long-term value. JAF is known for its wide range of wood materials and innovative solutions. What are the novelties in your offer, especially when we talk about materials such as compact panels, Corian and ALPI fineline veneers? - JAF is synonymous with variety and quality in the segment of wood and decorative materials. Our philosophy is to offer the market everything that modern design and architecture demand - from natural wood to the most modern composite materials. Today, compact panels are one of the most sought-after solutions, because they combine high resistance, stability and aesthetic versatility. They are ideal for areas with higher loads and hygiene requirements - such as hospitals, schools, kitchens and commercial facilities. Compact panels have found wide application in the exterior as well as ventilated facades. DuPont brand Corian® panels are a material that offers endless possibilities to architects and is used for countertops. JAF is the general distributor of the Italian ALPI brand. ALPI fineline veneers are a response to the growing need for innovative, ecologically stable and designerly recognizable surfaces. What sets us apart is the ability to offer the entire solution in one place - from materials to technical support and logistics - which saves our partners time and increases efficiency in project implementation. (Photo: JAF Srbija) In which direction are your products developing when it comes to sustainability, ecological standards and the application of new technologies in production? - Sustainability is not just a trend, but a fundamental part of our business philosophy. As a company with Austrian roots, JAF Group has been setting standards in the area of ​​responsible wood use and protection of natural resources for decades. All our products come from controlled and certified sources, which means that each tree has its own route and known origin - from the forest to the end user. This ensures that wood is used rationally and that afforestation is carried out in a planned manner. We also invest in the modernization of warehouses and machines that contribute to energy efficiency and waste reduction. In production processes, as well as in transport and packaging, the focus is on reducing CO₂ emissions and optimizing supply chains. At JAF, we believe that responsibility towards nature is an integral part of product quality - because sustainability and durability always go together. By opening a distribution center and a modern showroom in Niš, you have become even closer to customers in the south of Serbia. What can customers and partners expect in this new space? - Our new center in Niš represents an important strategic step in the development of JAF`s business in Serbia. With this, we completed our network and enabled more efficient distribution of materials to partners in the south of the country. It is a modern logistics and sales center with a large storage capacity, modern equipment and a showroom that offers complete inspiration for architects, carpentry workshops and investors. Customers can expect access to the widest range of board materials, parquet, veneers, decking systems and decorative surfaces, as well as expert advice from our team. Our goal is for every visitor to the Niš Center to experience JAF not only as a supplier, but as a partner who understands the needs of the local market and provides concrete solutions. A third of JAF`s employees are women, which is exceptional for a company in the wood industry. How does JAF promote balance and equal opportunity within its team? - At JAF, we are proud of the fact that a third of our employees are women - at all levels of the organization, from logistics and sales to management positions. It is not just a number, but a conscious decision to build a culture where knowledge, expertise and dedication are valued more than any stereotypes. We encourage equality of opportunity through open communication, clear criteria for promotion and continuous investment in professional development. I believe that diverse teams are more resilient, more creative and more successful – because they bring a wider range of ideas and approaches to solving challenges. It is precisely this combination of expertise and different worldviews that makes JAF distinctive. Melanija Pavlović (Photo: JAF Srbija) As a woman at the head of a large company, what challenges and opportunities do you see in leading a team in a predominantly technical and traditionally male-dominated industry? - Leadership in a traditionally male industry certainly brings challenges, but also enormous opportunities for a change of perspective. The key to success lies in competence, consistency and the ability to inspire the team to grow with you. From my experience, authority is not built through strength, but through knowledge and integrity. When people recognize that you are dedicated, fair and willing to support them, they follow you regardless of gender. The industry is changing - more and more women are entering the technical and managerial spheres, which contributes to a better balance and greater innovation. It is important that each of us be an example of moving the boundaries with knowledge and results. How does JAF support women`s empowerment within the company, and do you have initiatives that encourage greater involvement of women in this area? - Within the company, we are actively working on the development of women through mentoring, training programs and internal dialogue on career development. Our approach is to recognize the potential of each person and enable them to develop it - either through specialization in a certain business segment, or through taking on leadership roles. Externally, through various projects and public performances, we want to inspire other companies to follow a similar example - because when women have the opportunity, the entire organization becomes more stable, innovative and successful. What are the future plans of the JAF company in Serbia - when it comes to the development of new products, investments and business expansion? - Our plans are aimed at further growth and modernization. We are planning new investments in the development of the distribution network, additional process digitization and strengthening of the logistics infrastructure. Digital tools, such as online ordering platforms and virtual showrooms, are becoming an important part of our business because they enable customers to access materials and technical information more easily and quickly. At the same time, we are working on expanding our own brands in all segments, as well as educating the market through presentations and cooperation with architects, designers and contractors. Our goal is for JAF Serbia to remain a leader that sets standards - both in terms of quality and professionalism, as well as in terms of sustainable and responsible business operations. La sostenibilità non è per JAF una semplice tendenza, ma un pilastro della sua filosofia aziendale: da tempo l’azienda fissa standard nell’uso responsabile del legno e nella tutela delle risorse naturali, investendo inoltre nella modernizzazione di magazzini e macchinari per migliorare efficienza energetica e ridurre gli sprechi.

Un vantaggio competitivo è la capacità di offrire soluzioni complete in un unico punto, dall’approvvigionamento dei materiali al supporto tecnico e alla logistica, ottimizzando tempi e risultati per i partner. Particolare attenzione è dedicata a prodotti certificati FSC® e PEFC™.

Il nuovo centro distributivo e showroom di Niš rafforza la presenza nel sud della Serbia, offrendo un’ampia gamma di materiali e consulenza specializzata. L’azienda è anche impegnata nella promozione della parità di genere: un terzo dei dipendenti è donna, con ruoli attivi anche in posizioni manageriali. Pavlović sottolinea come la leadership efficace si basi su competenza e integrità, indipendentemente dal genere, e come la diversità rafforzi creatività e resilienza aziendale.

I piani futuri includono ulteriori investimenti nella rete distributiva, digitalizzazione dei processi e sviluppo di marchi propri, sempre con un occhio alla sostenibilità e all’innovazione. Come riportato da ekapija.com, l’obiettivo resta chiaro: mantenere il ruolo di leader di mercato per qualità, professionalità e responsabilità ambientale. Per le aziende italiane attive nel settore del legno, dei materiali da costruzione e dell’interior design, JAF rappresenta un partner strategico per l’accesso al mercato serbo, grazie alla sua rete distributiva, alla sua offerta certificata e all’attenzione alle tendenze internazionali in materia di sostenibilità e design.

title_en: SAT: Serbia lacks 216,000 tons of crude oil per month, 145 barges needed
title_it: Carenza di greggio in Serbia: servono 145 chiatte al mese
content_en: Pancevo Refinery (Photo: Adriana Iacob/shutterstock.com) To satisfy the market in Serbia, 216,000 tons of crude oil are needed per month, according to the data from SAT’s production company that was announced in the show of the same name on RTS. They calculated this by analyzing data on oil processing at the Pancevo Refinery in 2024. According to this data, 3.4 million tons of crude oil were processed in Pancevo this year. Of that, 800,000 tons were domestic oil, and 2.6 million tons were imported, via the Adriatic Oil Pipeline (JANAF). Now that oil cannot come through JANAF due to the introduction of US sanctions on the Serbian Oil Industry (NIS), SAT points out that other modes of transport do not provide a solution either. – If we count barges, the capacity of one is on average 1,500 tons, which means that at least 145 such vessels are needed to meet market demands. Travel time and reloading restrictions should be taken into account, which in the best case is 10 days. Barges are cheaper and more convenient than rail or road transport – states the SAT program. They pointed out that importing finished derivatives from neighboring countries was not a long-term sustainable solution, because the processing of crude oil was significantly cheaper, and that, in addition, it brought a whole range of products, such as liquefied petroleum gas, fuel oil, bitumen and the like. SAT added that “fuel shortages can only be alleviated slightly.” – Even with the mobilization of all means of transport and sufficient loading capacities, the fuel shortage can only be alleviated slightly. This opens the way for various machinations, such as fuel dilution – the analysis emphasizes. As a reminder, the Serbian Government plans to activate mandatory oil reserves. In addition, the government has passed a regulation that, in the event of an interruption in oil transport via JANAF, plans a series of measures, including “odd-even” driving and working from home. Per soddisfare il fabbisogno del mercato serbo sono necessarie 216.000 tonnellate di greggio al mese, secondo i dati della società produttrice del programma SAT, presentati nell’omonima trasmissione di RTS. Tale stima deriva dall’analisi della lavorazione del petrolio effettuata nel 2024 presso la raffineria di Pančevo: quest’anno sono state trattate 3,4 milioni di tonnellate di greggio, di cui 800.000 tonnellate provenienti dalla produzione nazionale e 2,6 milioni importate tramite l’oleodotto adriatico (JANAF).  

A seguito delle sanzioni statunitensi imposte alla Naftna Industrija Srbije (NIS), non è più possibile utilizzare il canale JANAF. Il programma SAT sottolinea che neppure altre modalità di trasporto rappresentano una soluzione efficace: una chiatta ha una capacità media di 1.500 tonnellate, pertanto ne servirebbero almeno 145 al mese per coprire il fabbisogno. Va inoltre considerato il tempo di viaggio e le limitazioni di carico, che nel migliore dei casi richiedono 10 giorni. Il trasporto fluviale risulta comunque più economico e conveniente rispetto a ferrovia o camion.  

SAT mette inoltre in guardia dal considerare l’importazione di derivati finiti dai Paesi vicini come una soluzione sostenibile a lungo termine, in quanto la raffinazione del greggio è notevolmente più conveniente e permette di ottenere una gamma più ampia di prodotti, tra cui GPL, olio combustibile e bitume.  

Anche mobilitando tutti i mezzi di trasporto disponibili e sfruttando al massimo le capacità di carico, la carenza di carburante potrebbe essere attenuata solo marginalmente, aprendo la strada a pratiche illecite come la diluizione del carburante.  

Come riportato da ekapija.com, il governo serbo intende attivare le riserve obbligatorie di petrolio e ha già adottato un regolamento che prevede, in caso di interruzione del flusso attraverso JANAF, misure come la circolazione “a targhe alterne” e lo smart working.  

Questa situazione potrebbe rappresentare un’opportunità per aziende italiane attive nel settore energetico e nella logistica petrolifera, in particolare per soluzioni di trasporto alternative e tecnologie per la lavorazione del greggio.

title_en: Council of the European Union adopts ban on Russian gas transit through EU to third countries – “Serbia in almost hopeless situation”
title_it: Divieto Ue al transito del gas russo verso Paesi terzi
content_en: (Photo: nostal6ie/shutterstock.com) The Council of the European Union yesterday agreed on its negotiating position on the draft regulation to phase out imports of Russian natural gas. The Council confirmed that imports of Russian gas will be prohibited from January 1, 2026, while maintaining a transition period for existing contracts. The proposed regulation introduces a legally binding, stepwise prohibition on both pipeline gas and liquefied natural gas (LNG) imports from Russia. A full ban should apply from January 1, 2028, the announcement says. Short-term contracts concluded before June 17, 2025, may continue until June 17, 2026, whereas long-term contracts may run until January 1, 2028. Amendments to existing contracts will be permitted only for narrowly defined operational purposes and cannot lead to increased volumes, except for some specific flexibilities for landlocked member states affected by recent changes in supply routes. The Council has also streamlined customs obligations by establishing lighter documentation requirements and procedures for imports of non-Russian gas. In such cases, only proof of the country of production must be provided to the authorizing authorities before gas enters the EU’s customs territory. The proof must be provided at least five days before entry. More information is requested for gas imports from Russia during the transitional phase, including the date and duration of the supply contract, the quantities contracted and any amendments to the contract. The information required for authorization must be submitted at least one month before entry. In the case of mixed LNG cargos, the documentation must prove the respective shares of Russian and non-Russian gas in the mixture, with only the non-Russian amounts being allowed to enter the EU. It also clarified the suspension clause, specifying which types of disruption to the security of supply could justify a temporary lifting of the import prohibition or of the prior authorization requirement. As the next step, the Council presidency will start negotiations with the European Parliament with a view to agreeing on the final text of the regulation, once the latter has adopted its position. Minister of Mining and Energy Dubravka Djedovic Handanovic stated that Serbia was in a very difficult and almost hopeless situation, after the Council of the European Union adopted a ban on the transit of Russian gas through the EU to third countries, and the measure comes into force on January 1, 2026. The minister stated that “the bottom line is that Bulgaria will not allow the flow of Russian gas through the Balkan Stream, which will also harm Serbia in the future.” – Thanks to the excellent relations of President Aleksandar Vucic with world leaders, we hope to find a solution and are doing everything in our power, but the situation is almost hopeless, taking into account the current situation regarding Naftna industrija Srbije. Our country, which is not a participant in any conflict, has found itself affected through no fault of its own – stated Djedovic Handanovic. B. P. Il Consiglio dell’Unione europea ha adottato la sua posizione negoziale sul regolamento volto a eliminare gradualmente le importazioni di gas naturale russo. Dal 1° gennaio 2026 sarà vietato l’ingresso di gas russo nell’UE, con un regime transitorio per i contratti esistenti: i contratti a breve termine stipulati entro il 17 giugno 2025 potranno proseguire fino al 17 giugno 2026, mentre quelli a lungo termine fino al 1° gennaio 2028. Il divieto definitivo si applicherà dal 2028. Sono previste limitate eccezioni operative per gli Stati membri senza sbocco al mare, senza tuttavia aumentare i volumi.  

Il Consiglio ha semplificato gli obblighi doganali per il gas non russo, richiedendo solo la prova del Paese di produzione almeno cinque giorni prima dell’ingresso nell’UE. Per il gas russo in transito durante la fase transitoria, è richiesta documentazione dettagliata, da presentare un mese prima dell’ingresso. Nei carichi misti di GNL, solo la quota non russa potrà entrare nel mercato UE.  

La ministra serba dell’Energia, Dubravka Đedović Handanović, ha dichiarato che la Serbia si trova in una “situazione quasi disperata” a causa del divieto UE al transito del gas russo verso Paesi terzi, in vigore dal 2026. “La Bulgaria non permetterà più il flusso di gas russo attraverso il Balkan Stream, danneggiando anche la Serbia”, ha affermato, sottolineando che il Paese, non coinvolto in alcun conflitto, subisce conseguenze non volute.  

Come riportato da ekapija.com, la presidenza del Consiglio avvierà ora negoziati con il Parlamento europeo per concordare il testo definitivo del regolamento. La misura potrebbe aprire opportunità per fornitori alternativi di gas e infrastrutture energetiche, anche per aziende italiane specializzate in soluzioni energetiche sostenibili e sicurezza degli approvvigionamenti.

title_en: Payment with Dina Card not to be possible either at NIS gas stations? – US issues warning to NBS, says president
title_it: Avvertimento USA su Dina Card e stazioni NIS
content_en: (Photo: Vedrana Marković) Serbian President Aleksandar Vucic said that the US, which had imposed sanctions on NIS due to its Russian stake, had issued a warning to the National Bank of Serbia for the “Dina Card” (DinaCard) as well regarding payments at gas stations. He announced talks with the US on the issue on TV Pink, telling Serbian citizens that they had no reason to worry and that the market would be well supplied. He said that the state, when it came to oil, gas and everything else, was doing everything it could and that people did not need to worry about heating and that there was enough fuel oil, gas and electricity. – We are already having problems with financial transactions and a warning has already been issued from the US for the NBS and the “Dina Card” (...) as far as payments at gas stations are concerned, there is no problem with cash – he said. He also said that the market would be well supplied, that diesel had become cheaper that day and that “people don’t have to worry about that.” – We don’t want to go back to the past, we are going into the future – said Vucic. “DinaCard” is the national payment card of Serbia, which is used to pay for goods and services and to withdraw cash, according to their website. “DinaCard system” was founded in 2003, as a result of cooperation between the NBS and commercial banks. Predsedništvo Republike Srbije Narodna banka Srbije Beograd president of Serbia National Bank of Serbia Aleksandar Vučić DinaCard Your comment Send
content_it: Il presidente serbo Aleksandar Vučić ha dichiarato che gli Stati Uniti, che avevano già imposto sanzioni a NIS a causa della sua partecipazione russa, hanno emesso un avvertimento anche alla Banca Nazionale di Serbia (NBS) riguardo alla carta di pagamento nazionale “Dina Card”, in relazione ai pagamenti presso le stazioni di servizio. Intervenendo su TV Pink, Vučić ha rassicurato i cittadini serbi, affermando che non vi è motivo di preoccupazione e che il mercato sarà adeguatamente rifornito. Ha sottolineato che lo Stato sta facendo tutto il possibile per garantire petrolio, gas ed energia, assicurando che ci sono scorte sufficienti di gasolio, gas ed elettricità per il riscaldamento. “Stiamo già avendo problemi con le transazioni finanziarie e un avvertimento è già stato inviato dagli USA alla NBS e alla Dina Card (...) per quanto riguarda i pagamenti alle stazioni di servizio, non ci sono problemi con il contante”, ha precisato. Ha inoltre annunciato che il gasolio è diventato più economico e che “la gente non deve preoccuparsi”. Vučić ha aggiunto: “Non vogliamo tornare al passato, stiamo andando verso il futuro”. La Dina Card, lanciata nel 2003 in collaborazione tra la NBS e le banche commerciali, è il sistema nazionale di pagamento della Serbia, utilizzato per acquistare beni e servizi e prelevare contante, come riportato da ekapija.com. La situazione potrebbe rappresentare un’opportunità per aziende italiane attive nei sistemi di pagamento elettronico o nell’approvvigionamento energetico alternativo.

title_en: Serbia to introduce tariffs for all phases of nuclear power plant construction through law amendments
title_it: Nuove tariffe per la costruzione di centrali nucleari
content_en: Illustration (Photo: Petr Louzensky/shutterstock.com) Serbia has opted for nuclear energy. This is clear to us, especially after the recent lifting of the moratorium on the construction of nuclear power plants. Amendments to some other laws, however, send a message that we are not that far from preparing for them. And no less than the Amendments to the Law on Republic Administrative Fees. First of all, the new version of the law provides for the introduction of the possibility of electronic payment of administrative fees. It also provides for the introduction of new bases for payment. Significant changes will thus be made to tariff number 200. It prescribes tariffs for all activities related to radiation activities and the use of ionizing radiation sources. The use of radioactive material and the preparation of a nuclear facility. These items are also among the most expensive. The three tariffs exceed - one million dinars. Selection of location for nuclear power plant - one million dinars Anyone who requests approval for a report on the selection of a location for the construction of a nuclear facility will pay – 1,090,210 dinars to the republican budget. The same amount is provided for approval upon request for a report on the design of a nuclear facility. Just as for approval for project changes made during the construction of a nuclear facility. But the tariff also provides for the following steps that are taken until electricity starts flowing from atomic energy. Thus, approval for a report on testing a nuclear facility without radioactive and nuclear materials will cost 408,830 dinars. The moment it is tested with radioactive and nuclear materials, it will cost 726,810 dinars. Approval for the temporary cessation of the operation of a nuclear facility will cost the same. Here we also encounter terms that we would not want to face in the context of a nuclear facility. Approval for site remediation and the rehabilitation of a contaminated facility is provided. It will cost 272,550 dinars. Just as much as approval for an updated decommissioning plan. Approval for a decommissioning report and a report on the final radiological inspection of the facility and site are charged at 726,810 dinars. A permit for the trade of radioactive material, radiation generators and other goods will cost 11,360 dinars. A permit for the transit of radioactive waste and spent nuclear fuel through Serbia will cost 90,850 dinars. content_it:
La Serbia ha optato per l'energia nucleare, come dimostrato dalla recente revoca del moratorio sulla costruzione di centrali nucleari. Ulteriori segnali provengono dalle modifiche alla Legge sulle tasse amministrative repubblicane, che introducono nuove tariffe per le varie fasi di realizzazione di un impianto nucleare. Tra le disposizioni più rilevanti, figurano costi elevati per attività legate alle radiazioni e all’uso di sorgenti di radiazione ionizzante. 

L’approvazione di una relazione sulla selezione del sito per una centrale nucleare comporterà un costo di 1.090.210 dinari serbi, cifra identica richiesta anche per l’approvazione del progetto dell’impianto e per le eventuali modifiche progettuali durante la costruzione. Altre tariffe significative riguardano la fase di collaudo: 408.830 dinari per i test senza materiali radioattivi e 726.810 dinari per quelli con materiali nucleari. Lo stesso importo è previsto per l'interruzione temporanea dell’esercizio dell’impianto.

Previsti anche costi per la bonifica del sito (272.550 dinari), per l’aggiornamento del piano di dismissione (272.550 dinari) e per la relazione finale di dismissione e ispezione radiologica (726.810 dinari). Infine, il permesso per il commercio di materiale radioattivo e generatori di radiazioni è fissato in 11.360 dinari, mentre il transito di rifiuti radioattivi e combustibile nucleare esausto attraverso il territorio serbo costerà 90.850 dinari, come riportato da ekapija.com.

Queste misure normative potrebbero aprire opportunità per aziende italiane specializzate in ingegneria nucleare, gestione dei rifiuti radioattivi e tecnologie di sicurezza, settori in cui l’Italia vanta competenze riconosciute a livello internazionale.

title_en: NIN: Most realistic option for Serbia to buy part of NIS ownership from Intelligence, minus one share
title_it: Serbia potrebbe rilevare quote NIS da Intelligence
content_en: (Photo: Shutterstock/Adam Radosavljevic) The problem with Naftna industrija Srbije (NIS), due to US sanctions, should be resolved by the New Year at the latest, and the most realistic option is for the state of Serbia to buy part of the 11.3% ownership of NIS, which is currently in the hands of Intelligence, practically a granddaughter of Gazprom, writes the NIN weekly, referring to its findings. Since the Russian companies Intelligence and Gazpromneft currently own a total of 56.15% of NIS (11.3% and 44.85%), such a transaction would make Serbia and small shareholders the majority owners. The Russian side also opposed this model in recent months, but it seems to have relented and agreed to it, but on the condition that Gazprom Intelligence would retain one share, and that a clause be included in the purchase agreement that the Russians have the right of first refusal when the situation calms down and sanctions on Russian companies are lifted. The New Year as the date for the final solution to the problem also fits in with the stocks of oil and derivatives that Serbia and NIS have, so it should not have any consequences for either the operation of the refinery in Pancevo or the supply of derivatives to the market, writes NIN. A less likely option is for Serbia to take over the management of NIS using a licensing model, and the least likely would involve a quick agreement on peace in Ukraine. NIS a.d. content_it: Secondo il settimanale NIN, il problema legato a Naftna industrija Srbije (NIS), causato dalle sanzioni statunitensi, dovrebbe risolversi entro il nuovo anno. L’opzione più realistica prevede che lo Stato serbo acquisisca l’11,3% di NIS attualmente detenuto da Intelligence, società controllata da Gazprom. Tale operazione porterebbe la Serbia e i piccoli azionisti a detenere la maggioranza, dato che le società russe Intelligence e Gazpromneft possiedono complessivamente il 56,15% di NIS. La parte russa, inizialmente contraria, avrebbe ora acconsentito, a condizione che a Gazprom Intelligence rimanga una singola azione e che nell’accordo sia inclusa una clausola di prelazione per il riacquisto delle quote una volta revocate le sanzioni. Questa tempistica garantirebbe continuità operativa alla raffineria di Pančevo e alla fornitura di derivati sul mercato. Altre opzioni, come l’assunzione della gestione tramite modello di licenza o un’immediata risoluzione del conflitto in Ucraina, sono considerate meno probabili. Come riportato da ekapija.com, l’operazione aprirebbe spazi per la stabilizzazione del settore energetico serbo, con potenziali opportunità per imprese italiane attive nella fornitura di tecnologie e servizi per il comparto oil & gas.

title_en: Fiscal Council: Implementation of CBAM principles to significantly increase price of Serbian export products on EU market, highest expected for cement, 40 to 60%
title_it: CBAM: +60% sui prezzi del cemento serbo in UE
content_en: Illustration (Photo: Pixabay.com/Life-Of-Pix) Serbia is lagging behind in meeting climate goals and therefore the introduction of the Carbon Border Adjustment Mechanism (CBAM), whose implementation in the European Union begins in 2026, will have far-reaching consequences for the Serbian economy, because this new climate regulation imposes additional costs on Serbian companies’ exports to the EU, which could amount to several hundred million euros per year next year, according to the report of the Fiscal Council of Serbia on the climate transition in Serbia. – In order for Serbia to catch up with the EU in this area, climate and energy policies must become an absolute priority of the Government. Energy and climate transition will be among the greatest strategic challenges for Serbia in the coming period, because these are processes that will shape electricity prices, affect the competitiveness of the economy, i.e. revenues and public expenditures. Decarbonization is the key to maintaining the competitiveness of domestic industry on the EU market, which is why investments in reducing greenhouse gas emissions and energy efficiency are needed to mitigate CBAM costs – said Blagoje Paunovic, President of the Fiscal Council, at the presentation of the report “Climate and Energy Transition of Serbia and Public Finances: Will CBAM Trigger Change?” He pointed out that the costs of implementing CBAM, i.e. paying the carbon footprint of the economy to Serbia, would be moderate at first, but that they would become significant later. Paunovic stated that, in 2026, costs for all industrial products should amount to around EUR 45 million, with the total CBAM obligations for that sector increasing to EUR 150 to 200 million in 2030. He explained that the implementation of the CBAM principle would lead to a significant increase in the price of Serbian export products to the EU market. – The highest price increase is expected for cement, from 40 to 60%, due to its low value in relation to the price of emissions. For iron and steel, prices are expected to increase by about 10 to 20%, for fertilizers by 10 to 15%, and for aluminum by about 5% – said Paunovic. He added that, since the levy would also apply to products from the EU, their price would also be higher, so the estimated average loss of price competitiveness of Serbian products on the EU market by 2030 would be four to five percentage points . As Paunovic said, Serbia has a significantly higher carbon footprint per unit of product than its EU competitors. – For industrial products, steel, cement and aluminum, emissions are 15 to 20% higher, while the most drastic difference is in electricity production, because greenhouse gas emissions in Serbia are three to four times higher than in the EU – said Paunovic. He explained that the reason for such a large deviation from the EU average was Serbia’s long-standing delay and lagging behind in climate policies. As he pointed out, the main cause of the problem is the production of electricity from lignite in Elektroprivreda Srbije (EPS), because almost 80% of greenhouse gas emissions come from the energy sector , of which the production of electricity and heat accounts for about 50%. Paunovic stated that Serbia was late in meeting its climate goals to which it had committed itself under international agreements. According to him, from 2010 to 2023, greenhouse gas emissions in Serbia were reduced by 3.4%, and in the countries of Central and Eastern Europe by about 20%. – Apart from a lot being done on the standards, little has been achieved in practice – said Paunovic. The report states that Serbia has almost twice as many greenhouse gas emissions per unit of product as the average for Central and Eastern Europe , and there are two key reasons - low energy efficiency and a poor energy mix structure. Serbia consumes 55% more energy per unit of GDP than the average for Central and Eastern Europe due to outdated technologies in industry, poor insulation of buildings, and high losses in energy transmission. content_it:
La Serbia è in ritardo nel raggiungimento degli obiettivi climatici e l’introduzione del Meccanismo di adeguamento del carbonio alle frontiere (CBAM), che entrerà in vigore nell’Unione europea dal 2026, avrà conseguenze rilevanti per l’economia serba. Secondo il rapporto del Consiglio fiscale serbo sulla transizione climatica, questa nuova normativa imporrà costi aggiuntivi alle esportazioni serbe verso l’UE, stimati in diverse centinaia di milioni di euro annui a partire dal prossimo anno.  

Blagoje Paunović, presidente del Consiglio fiscale, ha sottolineato che politiche climatiche ed energetiche devono diventare priorità assoluta del Governo serbo. La transizione energetica rappresenterà una delle principali sfide strategiche per il Paese, influenzando prezzi dell’elettricità, competitività economica, entrate e spese pubbliche. Investimenti in efficienza energetica e riduzione delle emissioni sono essenziali per mitigare l’impatto del CBAM.

I costi iniziali saranno contenuti – circa 45 milioni di euro nel 2026 per i prodotti industriali – ma saliranno a 150-200 milioni di euro entro il 2030. L’aumento dei prezzi delle esportazioni serbe nell’UE sarà particolarmente marcato per il cemento, con un rincaro stimato tra il 40% e il 60%, seguito da acciaio e ferro (10-20%), fertilizzanti (10-15%) e alluminio (circa 5%).  

La Serbia presenta un’intensità di emissioni significativamente superiore rispetto alla media UE: per acciaio, cemento e alluminio le emissioni sono del 15-20% più elevate, mentre nella produzione elettrica sono tre-quattro volte superiori, a causa della forte dipendenza dal lignite, che da solo genera quasi l’80% delle emissioni nazionali.  

Tra il 2010 e il 2023, le emissioni serbe si sono ridotte solo del 3,4%, contro il 20% dei Paesi dell’Europa centrale e orientale. L’inefficienza energetica e la struttura del mix energetico – con tecnologie obsolete, edifici poco isolati e perdite nella trasmissione – rendono la Serbia meno competitiva.  

Come riportato da ekapija.com, le imprese italiane potrebbero trovare opportunità nel supportare la Serbia nella transizione energetica, fornendo tecnologie per l’efficienza energetica, soluzioni di decarbonizzazione e know-how per modernizzare il settore energetico e industriale.

title_en: Vlahovic for eKapija: Most likely solution for NIS is selling Gazpromneft’s stake to existing partners
title_it: Soluzione per NIS: cessione delle quote di Gazpromneft
content_en: (Photo: Media Biro) Nationalization of Naftna industrija Srbije (NIS) should not be an option, believes Aleksanadar Vlahovic, president of the Association of Economists of Serbia and former Minister of Economy and Privatization. As he said, one of the options could be bankruptcy, but the most likely solution is the sale of Gazpromneft’s stake in the company to existing partners. As Vlahovic told eKapija, sanctions against NIS were announced back in January of this year, and their implementation has been postponed several times. – I believe that the Serbian Government has done everything to find a solution before the sanctions come into force. The biggest problem is that Gazprom needs to exit NIS ownership, or rather majority ownership in the company, in order for the sanctions to be lifted, and that is decided by the Russian side. In that case, Serbia’s hands are pretty much tied. The other day, talks were held with the Russian delegation, more precisely with the Chairman of the Board of Directors of Gazprom, Aleksandr Dyukov, and as far as I can see, they were assessed as quite positive and successful – says Vlahovic. Considering that the Serbian Government announced that the refinery would operate completely undisturbed until the end of this month thanks to the previously defined stocks, Vlahovic believes that, if the issue of sanctions is resolved in the next month, or month and a half, they will not pose a major problem for Serbia. – However, the problem will arise in the supply of petroleum products sometime after the New Year, when a significant contingent coming from the Pancevo refinery - that is more than 60 percent of the total consumption of petroleum products - needs to be replaced by imports. Here, I believe, the issue of logistics and the import of petroleum products is key – says Vlahovic, adding that he is not sure that Serbia can logistically ensure the supply of petroleum products from alternative sources at this moment. – On the other hand, I hope that in the end, the talks between the Serbian and Russian sides will reach a solution - even if Gazpromneft sells its majority stake to a third party, and not directly to the state. Vlahovic says that the state, for its part, has an obligation to ensure the stability of the energy system, that is, the stability of the supply and consumption of petroleum products. – Therefore, if no final agreement is reached, I believe that there are mechanisms that will force the other side to make greater efforts in the coming period in order to find a solution – says eKapija’s interviewee. Given that in recent days we have been able to hear different scenarios for NIS - nationalization, introduction of bankruptcy, purchase of shares by the state of Serbia or some other partner, we asked Vlahovic which of these possibilities is the most likely. According to him, nationalization should not be an option. – That would be an attack on private property and would further jeopardize the level of risk of investing in our country, which is already quite high due to the lack of institutional integration – Vlahovic stated. When it comes to bankruptcy, he believes that it can be an option in itself if the company itself creates the conditions for bankruptcy through its operations, and that will depend on its operations in the coming period. – Therefore, I believe that the Russian side will sell that part of the share package, which will enable Gazpromneft to become a minority owner. Will it do it directly to the state through some possible forward sale, where the Russian side would have the option to, after the conflict that exists between Russia and America in terms of foreign policy is over, later buy back those shares - or will the Russian side find a partner it trusts more and sell to that third party, I don’t know. But I am sure that both sides will be respected in this way – he says. When asked how the crisis with Naftna industrija Srbije will affect the Serbian economy, if an adequate solution is not found soon, Vlahovic replies that NIS means a lot to Serbia in fiscal terms, considering that around 15% of the budget is filled from excise duty collection - not only from NIS, but from the total consumption of petroleum products. – In other words, it is certain that, if there is a shortage or a decrease in the consumption of petroleum products, it will have an impact on the budget. However, I still think that this is just the tip of the iceberg. Essentially, both the Serbian economy and the economies of the Western Balkans have deeper problems. This is the insufficient institutional development of the business environment – he says. On the other hand, he adds, the development model that has been accepted in most Western Balkan countries, which forces the so-called traditional branches of industry that do not contribute to rapid productivity growth and do not contribute to technological progress, is also questionable. – Economic policy needs to make a step forward in the coming period through a different approach, that is, through the activation of industrial policy mechanisms, which have been quite forgotten in this region – Vlahovic concludes in an interview with eKapija. Dragana Obradovic NIS a.d. content_it:
Aleksandar Vlahović, presidente dell’Associazione degli Economisti della Serbia e già ministro dell’Economia e della Privatizzazione, esclude la nazionalizzazione di Naftna industrija Srbije (NIS) come opzione percorribile. Secondo quanto riportato da ekapija.com, Vlahović ritiene che la soluzione più probabile sia la vendita della partecipazione di Gazpromneft a soci già presenti nella compagine azionaria.  

Le sanzioni contro NIS, annunciate a gennaio, sono state più volte rimandate. Vlahović sottolinea che il governo serbo ha fatto il possibile per trovare una soluzione prima dell’entrata in vigore delle misure, ma il nodo cruciale resta l’uscita di Gazprom dalla maggioranza azionaria, decisione che spetta alla controparte russa. Recentemente, i colloqui con Aleksandr Dyukov, presidente del consiglio di amministrazione di Gazprom, sono stati valutati positivamente.

Il governo serbo ha assicurato il funzionamento indisturbato della raffineria di Pančevo fino a fine mese grazie alle scorte disponibili. Tuttavia, Vlahović avverte che dopo il nuovo anno potrebbero sorgere problemi di approvvigionamento, poiché oltre il 60% dei prodotti petroliferi consumati in Serbia proviene proprio da questa raffineria. La logistica degli approvvigionamenti alternativi rappresenta una sfida non trascurabile.

Vlahović ribadisce che la nazionalizzazione danneggerebbe ulteriormente la fiducia degli investitori, già compromessa dalla scarsa integrazione istituzionale. Il fallimento resterebbe un’opzione soltanto in caso di deterioramento operativo di NIS. Più probabile è che Gazpromneft ceda la maggioranza, magari a un terzo fidato o tramite un accordo con opzione di riacquisto futuro.

NIS contribuisce significativamente alle entrate fiscali della Serbia: circa il 15% del bilancio deriva dalle accise sui carburanti. Una riduzione dei consumi avrebbe quindi un impatto diretto sulle finanze pubbliche. Tuttavia, Vlahović sottolinea che la crisi di NIS è solo la punta dell’iceberg di problemi strutturali più ampi, tra cui un modello di sviluppo incentrato su settori tradizionali poco produttivi e un’insufficiente politica industriale.  

Per le imprese italiane, il contesto energetico serbo potrebbe aprire opportunità nell’approvvigionamento di prodotti raffinati o nella fornitura di tecnologie per la logistica energetica, qualora la Serbia dovesse diversificare le sue fonti di importazione.

title_en: Vucic after meeting with Russians: There will be no oil shortage and no major energy crisis in Serbia
title_it: Nessuna crisi energetica in Serbia
content_en: (Photo: Vedrana Marković) Serbian President Aleksandar Vucic said that there would be no major energy crisis in Serbia due to the introduction of US sanctions on Naftna industrija Srbije (NIS) due to the majority Russian ownership in that company. He said this after a meeting with Chairman of the Board of Directors of Gazpromneft Aleksandr Dyukov and Deputy Minister of Energy of Russia Pavel Sorokin. – There will be no shortage of oil and oil products – Vucic said in a video statement on Instagram. He asked the citizens to remain calm. – We have just completed important talks with the Russian delegation on the issue of NIS. I am satisfied with the openness, constructiveness and honesty. We were both like that – said Vucic. He reiterated that “the times are not easy and there is no small burden ahead of us, but what I can say to the citizens of Serbia is - there will be no shortage of oil, oil products, or any major energy crisis in Serbia.” NIS a.d. content_it: Il presidente serbo Aleksandar Vučić ha dichiarato che la Serbia non affronterà carenze di petrolio né una grave crisi energetica nonostante le sanzioni statunitensi imposte alla Naftna industrija Srbije (NIS), dovute alla sua maggioranza azionaria russa. L’annuncio è stato fatto dopo un incontro con Aleksandr Dyukov, presidente del consiglio di amministrazione di Gazpromneft, e Pavel Sorokin, viceministro dell’Energia della Russia. In un messaggio video pubblicato su Instagram, Vučić ha esortato i cittadini a rimanere calmi, definendo i colloqui con la delegazione russa “aperti, costruttivi e onesti”. Ha ribadito che, sebbene i tempi siano difficili e le sfide significative, “non vi sarà alcuna carenza di petrolio, prodotti petroliferi o crisi energetica di rilievo in Serbia”, come riportato da ekapija.com. L’evoluzione della situazione energetica in Serbia potrebbe rappresentare un contesto d’interesse per le imprese italiane attive nel settore energetico e nella gestione delle crisi di approvvigionamento.

title_en: CWP Europe and the European Commission to Advance Renewable Energy in Albania and Montenegro
title_it: NON PERTINENT
content_en: (Photo: CWP Europe) During the EU-Western Balkans Investment Forum in Tirana, CWP Europe, together with the European Commission (DG ENEST), the Albanian Investment Development Agency, and the Montenegro Investment Promotion Agency, signed a Joint Declaration of Support for CWP’s two landmark renewable energy projects - the Tropoja Wind Farm in Albania and the Montechevo Solar Farm with Battery Storage in Montenegro. The signing took place in the presence of Edi Rama, Prime Minister of the Republic of Albania, and Ursula von der Leyen, President of the European Commission, who emphasized the Western Balkans’ increasing role in Europe’s clean energy transition. – Today you are signing several investments that will do just that. From clean energy production in all six Western Balkan partners. To energy storage in Montenegro. They will bring the cost of electricity down. And they will also contribute to our collective energy independence. You are building a new energy backbone not only for the Western Balkans. But for all of Europe – said President von der Leyen. CWP Europe’s CEO Dimitar Enchev signed the Declaration on behalf of the company, alongside Executive Vice Presidents Maja Turkovic and Viktor Garbev, who are set to participate as speakers at the investment forums in Tirana and Montenegro. – As the region replaces aging coal assets with cleaner, more affordable renewable energy, the opportunity to build a resilient and sustainable energy system is immense. With Tropoja and Montechevo, we are unlocking the region’s immense renewable energy potential and strengthening cooperation across the Western Balkans. We greatly appreciate the support of the European Commission, the Albanian Investment Development Agency, and the Montenegro Investment Promotion Agency in advancing this shared vision for a clean, economically competitive and secure energy future of the region and Europe as a whole – said Dimitar Enchev, CEO at CWP Europe. (Photo: CWP Europe) The 600 MW Tropoja Wind Farm will advance Albania’s energy independence by providing clean, affordable electricity - supporting the country’s energy strategy. In Montenegro, the 400 MW Montechevo Solar Farm will combine solar generation with battery storage directly connected to the country’s new 400 kV transmission grid. The project will leverage Montenegro’s strategic interconnections - including the undersea HVDC cable to Italy - to maximize the export of clean electricity and its integration into the European energy market. These initiatives demonstrate CWP Europe’s leadership in developing large-scale renewable energy projects across Southeast Europe and its continued contribution to a sustainable, resilient, and competitive regional energy future. ### About CWP Europe: CWP Europe is a leading renewable energy project development company in Southeast Europe. Over the past 17 years, CWP has invested in sustainable development and the energy transition, successfully developing the largest wind farms in the region, including the largest wind farm in Europe - the 600 MW Fantanele-Cogealac project in Romania. It is currently developing over 7 GW of renewable energy project capacity. CWP Europe is a joint venture between CWP Global, a leading global renewable energy company, and Mercuria Energy Trading, one of the world’s largest independent energy traders with over USD 140 billion in revenue. title_en: EPS: Drought brings hydropower plant production down to historic low
title_it: Produzione idroelettrica ai minimi storici
content_en: HPP Djerdap (Photo: Erich Westendarp from Pixabay) Due to extremely unfavorable hydrological conditions in the second drought year in a row, electricity production in the hydroelectric power plants of Elektroprivreda Srbije (EPS) this year will be the lowest in the history of EPS production, the company announced. The cause of the poor hydrological situation is the extremely low amounts of precipitation in the Drina and Danube basins in the last 18 months, the EPS statement said, as reported by RTS. The lack of precipitation (snow, rain) in Germany, Austria, Slovenia, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Montenegro, has affected the water levels of the Drina and Danube in Serbia, and periodic rainy periods this year in our country, as well as recent precipitation, have no impact on the inflow to our hydroelectric power plants. Since the beginning of the year, hydroelectric capacities have produced around 6.5 billion kilowatt-hours of electricity, and the final result will depend on whether and to what extent the hydrological situation improves in the coming months, EPS stated. As pointed out, it is certain that hydropower production in 2025 will be about 25% lower than last year, and even 40% lower than in 2023, when hydropower plants produced 12.66 billion kilowatt-hours of electricity. It is stated that the expectations are that the production of hydropower plants will be about eight billion kilowatt-hours, which is less than the lowest annual figure so far of 8.3 billion kilowatt-hours recorded 36 years ago. – The revitalizations carried out in the hydropower plants “Djerdap 1,” “Bajina Basta,” “Zvornik” have contributed to the fact that the renovated units operate with extremely high readiness and efficiency and convert every drop of water into energy – explains EPS. However, the inflows on the rivers always dictate production, and on the Drina and Danube, where the largest HPPs in EPS are located, during all months of this year they were far lower than the multi-year averages. The low water level is also evidenced by the fact that during this and last year there were periods when the Danube was not navigable, the statement says. Since the beginning of this century, the multi-year average inflow on the Danube has been 5,257 cubic meters per second, and during this year it was only 3,822 cubic meters per second. The Drina, as stated, has a similar situation, with very low inflows recorded during the last six months, and the average inflow in 2025 is only 239 cubic meters per second, almost 100 cubic meters less than the multi-year average, EPS states. – On the other hand, it is very important that the reserves in the reservoirs are managed carefully and in a planned manner in order to preserve them for the upcoming winter season – the statement says. content_it:
A causa di condizioni idrologiche estremamente sfavorevoli, con il secondo anno consecutivo di siccità, la produzione di energia elettrica negli impianti idroelettrici di Elektroprivreda Srbije (EPS) raggiungerà nel 2025 il livello più basso della sua storia, secondo quanto annunciato dall’azienda. La causa principale è la scarsità di precipitazioni nei bacini del Danubio e della Drina negli ultimi 18 mesi, con effetti negativi derivanti anche dalla mancanza di piogge e neve in Germania, Austria, Slovenia, Bosnia ed Erzegovina e Montenegro. Le piogge occasionali in Serbia quest’anno non hanno inciso significativamente sugli afflussi agli impianti.  

Da inizio anno, la produzione idroelettrica si attesta intorno a 6,5 miliardi di chilowattora. Si prevede che il totale annuo si aggiri sugli 8 miliardi, al di sotto del precedente minimo storico di 8,3 miliardi registrato 36 anni fa. Ciò rappresenta un calo del 25% rispetto al 2024 e del 40% rispetto al 2023, quando furono prodotti 12,66 miliardi di kWh.  

Gli afflussi al Danubio nel 2025 sono stati di 3.822 metri cubi al secondo, ben al di sotto della media pluridecennale di 5.257 m³/s. Situazione analoga si registra sulla Drina, con una media di soli 239 m³/s, quasi 100 in meno rispetto alla media storica. Nonostante i lavori di ristrutturazione negli impianti di Đerdap 1, Bajina Bašta e Zvornik abbiano migliorato l’efficienza delle turbine, la produzione rimane vincolata alla disponibilità idrica. EPS sottolinea inoltre l’importanza di gestire con cura le riserve nei bacini in vista della prossima stagione invernale, come riportato da ekapija.com.  

Per le imprese italiane attive nel settore energetico e nella gestione delle risorse idriche, questa situazione potrebbe rappresentare un’opportunità per proporre soluzioni tecnologiche e gestionali volte a ottimizzare l’efficienza idroelettrica in condizioni di scarsità d’acqua.

title_en: Djedovic Handanovic: We have not heard a plan or program for NIS from the Russian side
title_it: NIS: Nessun piano da Mosca, preoccupazione a Belgrado
content_en: (Photo: Shutterstock/dr Igi) Minister of Mining and Energy Dubravka Djedovic Handanovic stated that at the urgent extraordinary session of the board of directors, representatives of the management of Naftna industrija Srbije (NIS) had not heard “either a plan or a program,” which she assessed as “worrying.” In an appearance on RTS, she stated that the meeting was held at the initiative of Serbian representatives of the board and added that Chairman of the Executive Board of Gazpromneft Aleksandr Dyukov and Deputy Minister of Energy of Russia Pavel Sorokin would come to Belgrade and meet with President of Serbia Aleksandar Vucic on Monday. – We have previously spoken with our Russian partners, their plan was to wait for the war in Ukraine to end, for an agreement to be reached between Russia and the US, that this would affect the sanctions, but that we are witnesses that this did not happen, that sanctions had been introduced. In the coming days, we expect to hear the plan of the Russian partners, what they have thought up... We expect proposals and a plan, not for the next few weeks, but for three, four, five, six months, in order to ensure security of supply and the operation of the refinery in Pancevo – said Djedovic Handanovic. She added that the sanctions against NIS had been announced in December 2024, that they had been postponed several times, and that at the meeting they had also heard that the company’s management hoped that Vucic would “find a solution at a higher level.” – But he does not have a magic wand. We repeat: what is the plan for the supply of crude oil, the operation of the refinery in Pancevo, for more than 13,000 employees, and for this plan not to include the passage of time... Let the plan not  be that time passes, that December comes and that the plan is not there yet, because we expect that Serbia’s interests will be protected, that our energy security will be protected – stated Djedovic Handanovic. She also stated that Serbia did not want to nationalize anyone’s property, that it was “scandalous” that property, primarily Russian, was “being seized in Europe today” and that Serbia wanted to be a safe place for investors. When asked whether domestic fuel supplies were already being used up, the minister stated that she expected a new delivery of 50,000 tons of derivatives that had already been paid for, that there were enough reserves and that citizens should not be afraid, but that the Russian side announced the day before that it had crude oil for the refinery in Pancevo until November 1, and that NIS had its own supplies that could only last until the beginning of December. content_it:
La ministra serba dell’Energia e delle Miniere, Dubravka Đedović Handanović, ha dichiarato che durante la sessione straordinaria del consiglio di amministrazione di Naftna industrija Srbije (NIS), i rappresentanti della gestione non hanno ricevuto “né un piano né un programma” dalla parte russa, una situazione che ha definito “preoccupante”. Intervenendo su RTS, ha riferito che l’incontro è stato convocato su iniziativa dei consiglieri serbi e che il presidente del consiglio esecutivo di Gazpromneft, Aleksandr Dyukov, e il viceministro russo dell’Energia, Pavel Sorokin, saranno a Belgrado lunedì per incontrare il presidente serbo Aleksandar Vučić.

“In passato i nostri partner russi ci avevano detto di voler attendere la fine della guerra in Ucraina e un accordo tra Russia e Stati Uniti, nella speranza che ciò portasse a un allentamento delle sanzioni – ha spiegato la ministra – ma constatiamo che ciò non è avvenuto. Nei prossimi giorni ci aspettiamo di conoscere il loro piano concreto, non per le prossime settimane, ma per i prossimi tre-sei mesi, al fine di garantire la sicurezza degli approvvigionamenti e il funzionamento della raffineria di Pančevo”.

Ha aggiunto che le sanzioni contro NIS, annunciate a dicembre 2024, sono state più volte rimandate e che la direzione aziendale spera che il presidente Vučić “trovi una soluzione a livello politico più elevato”, pur sottolineando che “non possiede una bacchetta magica”. Ha insistito sulla necessità di un piano chiaro per la fornitura di greggio, il funzionamento della raffineria e la tutela degli oltre 13.000 dipendenti, escludendo che il semplice trascorrere del tempo possa costituire una strategia.

La Serbia, ha chiarito, non intende nazionalizzare beni altrui e condanna il sequestro di proprietà, in particolare russe, in corso in Europa, auspicando di rimanere un Paese sicuro per gli investitori. Riguardo alle scorte nazionali di carburante, ha rassicurato che arriverà presto una consegna di 50.000 tonnellate di prodotti raffinati già pagati e che le riserve sono sufficienti. Tuttavia, la parte russa ha comunicato di avere greggio per la raffineria di Pančevo fino al 1° novembre, mentre le scorte autonome di NIS dureranno solo fino all’inizio di dicembre, come riportato da ekapija.com.

L’incertezza sul futuro di NIS e le pressioni sanzionatorie creano un contesto in cui potrebbero aprirsi opportunità per aziende italiane nei settori energetico e petrolchimico, qualora la Serbia dovesse riconsiderare i propri partenariati strategici.

title_en: New mining explosives production plant launched at Tvek factory in Ljubija – Investment of 8.5 million convertible marks
title_it: Nuovo impianto per esplosivi minerari in Bosnia
content_en: (Photo: predsjednikrs.rs/Dona Katušić) President Milorad Dodik launched a new mining explosives production plant at the “Tvek” factory in Ljubija near Prijedor. The “Tvek” factory produces, stores and transports mining explosives, and provides drilling and blasting services, international transport of cargo and dangerous goods, as well as civilian shooting range services. The mixed-ownership company Explosives Factory “Tvek Ljubija” has been operating since 2002. Director of the “Tvek” Factory Dusko Dolinic thanked President Milorad Dodik for the great help he had provided in completing the project to build a new mining explosives production plant on time. – We excavated and transported 80,000 cubic meters of poor-quality material from this area, upgraded and installed 40,000 cubic meters, built a 2.5-kilometer power line and a four-kilometer water supply network. We installed more than 2,000 cubic meters, mainly in the explosives warehouse, which resulted in an investment of 8.5 million marks – said Dolinic and thanked the Mayor of Prijedor, Slobodan Javor, who continuously monitored the work of this factory and helped in every phase of this project. He invited investors planning business investments to visit Prijedor and highlighted the positive experiences they had had while cooperating with the Prijedor City Administration. content_it: Il presidente Milorad Dodik ha inaugurato un nuovo impianto per la produzione di esplosivi minerari presso la fabbrica “Tvek” a Ljubija, nei pressi di Prijedor. La fabbrica “Tvek”, attiva dal 2002, produce, immagazzina e trasporta esplosivi per uso minerario, offre servizi di perforazione e brillamento, trasporto internazionale di merci e materiali pericolosi, nonché servizi per poligoni di tiro civili. Il direttore della fabbrica, Duško Dolinić, ha ringraziato il presidente Dodik per il supporto fondamentale nella realizzazione puntuale del progetto, che ha comportato lo scavo e il trasporto di 80.000 metri cubi di materiale di scarsa qualità, il posizionamento di 40.000 metri cubi di materiale di riporto, la costruzione di una linea elettrica di 2,5 chilometri e di una rete idrica di quattro chilometri, oltre all’installazione di oltre 2.000 metri cubi di infrastrutture, principalmente nel magazzino esplosivi. L’investimento complessivo ammonta a 8,5 milioni di marchi convertibili. Dolinić ha inoltre ringraziato il sindaco di Prijedor, Slobodan Javor, per il costante monitoraggio e il sostegno in ogni fase del progetto, invitando altri investitori a considerare Prijedor come destinazione per nuovi investimenti grazie alla collaborazione positiva con l’amministrazione comunale. Come riportato da ekapija.com, il settore degli esplosivi industriali in Bosnia-Erzegovina presenta opportunità per aziende italiane specializzate in tecnologie per l’estrazione mineraria e nella fornitura di impianti industriali ad alta sicurezza.

title_en: Free Zone Pirot signs Memorandum of Cooperation with four high-tech Chinese industrial parks
title_it: Accordo tra Zona Franca Pirot e parchi cinesi
content_en: Illustration (Photo: Shutterstock/4045) Free Zone Pirot, as part of the Serbian delegation, at the 11th World Free Zones Organization Annual Congress held in China, is one of seven international free zones and institutions that have signed a Memorandum of Cooperation with Chinese industrial parks. The memorandum was signed in the city of Haikou in Hainan Province with four high-tech industrial parks (Haikou Jiandong New Area, Haikou Fullsing Internet Industrial Park, Hainan Resort Software Community, Overseas Returnees Town Limgshui). As announced, in addition to signing the memorandum, numerous contacts were established with representatives of Chinese zones and institutions with whom further cooperation, exchange of experiences and investments are expected.
